Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Blaine Smith, a Black man who is one of the heirs of 600 acres that came into their family in the 1920s, said in a statement: “We’re determined to keep fighting against this attempt to take our ancestral land from us.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Blaine Smith is directly affected by the decision and is a key stakeholder in the case.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We want to keep our property whole, so we can pass it down to our children and they can continue to build generational wealth,” Smith added.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Blaine Smith is directly affected by the decision and is a key stakeholder in the case.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Georgia law does not permit a private company to take land through eminent domain unless the land will be put to a public use,” said Bill Maurer, senior attorney for Institute for Justice who represents the landowners.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bill Maurer is the legal representative for the landowners and provides expert legal opinion.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The reality is if you’ve ever lived near a train, or you’ve ever ridden on a train or been near a train, it’s not the same as trucks driving by,” Rush said last year. “Even if the train is not going through your property, the fact that a train is near your property — all of the noise pollution, the vibrations of a train … all of that affects your property value, your peace of mind and your home.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Jamie Rush represents the No Railroad In Our Community Coalition and provides expert legal and environmental opinion.
